snippet: A Canadian electrical power plant, owned by Nova Scotia Power, is chipping away at the three-story-high, blocklong pile of petroleum coke on Detroit’s waterfront.
abstract: Canadian electrical power plant owned by Nova Scotia Power has begun purchasing and removing massive pile of petroleum coke on Detroit waterfront; coke, byproduct of processing heavy bitumen piped from oil sands in Alberta, will be used by utility for fuel; environmentalist warn that petroleum coke is particularly high emitter of greenhouse gas, and that its use threatens to derail conversion to cleaner natural gas.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian electrical power plant, owned by Nova Scotia Power, is chipping away at the three-story-high, blocklong pile of petroleum coke on Detroit’s waterfront.

headline.seo: Huge Petroleum Coke Pile Makes Way Back to Canada
headline.main: Canadian Utility Finds a Use for Detroit’s Pile of Oil Sands Byproduct
headline.print_headline: Canadian Utility Finds A Use for Detroit’s Pile Of Oil Sands Byproduct
